6. Despite following the "rules", things may still break. People change. You may want to see other coauthors. That's cool. You will probably make what seems like a "mistake" in choosing a coauthor. That's life. Your past relationships are just getting you ready for "the one".

5. Follow the "heck yeah" rule. If the answer to whether you should be on the project is not "heck yeah", then the answer is "no". Once projects leave the "honeymoon" phase, it gets real. Submitting papers and dealing with referee reports is like going to Ikea with your S.O.

4. If anyone offers a co-authorship, ask for 24 hrs. "I'm honored to be asked to be a coauthor with you, but I need to think about it for 24 hrs. I'm already committed to several projects and don't want to commit to a new project and disappoint you. b/c I respect you so much."

3. Communicate honest needs and constraints. "I've got to get this paper done by 2021 when I go up for tenure". "I've got tenure and I'm really busy because I am on the `committee on committees' " (yes, that committee exists)

2. Put those expectations in writing. Send a follow up email with what you understand the expectations to be. Use emoticons to make the email friendly (if that's what takes the edge off). I like the  emoticon because it looks like me if I wore glasses.

1. Set expectations early. Have a frank discussion. "I'm going to handle the heavy lifting on writing the intro". "I'll take charge on creating the exhibits". "I'll provide feedback once every two weeks".

@jayshimshack @cjfettweis There are animal experiments to back up the humidity-influenza link, too. This work (Shaman and Kohn) show that it's really low ABSOLUTE humidity that's the strongest predictor of influenza. See: http://www.pnas.org/content/106/9/3243.full

@cjfettweis Great question. Low absolute humidity is bad b/c it causes dehydration and cardiovascular stress, respiratory stress, and (my personal fav) influenza. @jayshimshack and I found that low humidity can predict a lot of influenza mortality in the US. See:https://academic.oup.com/aje/article/176/suppl_7/S114/112150

Here's some data from my own work on the dangers of low humidity levels. Basically, mortality risk goes up as the air becomes drier. I measure "the dryness of the air" using grams of water vapor per kilogram of air. It's pretty similar to using dew point.pic.twitter.com/59IMnLUgiu
Protect yourself and read this thread. Low ABSOLUTE humidity is dangerous. See:https://twitter.com/kejames/status/947255768147021824
